Traffic Needs



absence of the rail system, would be traveling by automobile.
This many persons would be traveling in about 7,000 cars.

We thus have varying estimates of a potential reduction of cars
coming into the central business district for employment purposes of
12,000, 10,000 and 7,000.

The first two figures are in the nature of theoretical maximums and
as a practical matter are obviously too high. The third is undoubtedly
more realistic, but even this estimate may be optimistic. Since it is based
upon 1980 population figures it certainly overstates present possibilities.
Nevertheless, let us accept this figure for the purpose of discussion. As-
suming an average round trip of 20 miles per day 7,000 cars would
generate 140,000 vehicle miles per day. This compares with 12,000,000
vehicle miles per day now being traveled in the Baltimore metropolitan
area and 20,000,000 vehicle miles per day predicted by 1980. Evidently

v ,+the elimination of 7,000 cars will not seriously alter the traffic problem.

Furthermore, the greatest concentration of homes of downtown employees
is to the north, and since the 7,000 car estimate is based upon a possible
rail system extending only in a northerly direction from the central busi-
ness district, the car travel which such a rail system might eliminate
would be north-south traffic. The east-west traffic which serves as one of
the main justifications for the Kast-West Expressway would hardly be
affected.

None of these points should be taken as meaning that there is no
need to establish a much improved and more comprehensive system of
public transportation. For one thing, the basic strength of the central
business district is in its accessibility to all parts of the metropolitan area.
This means accessibility in terms of all types of transportation—not just
automobile transportation. An improvement in public transportation to
the central business district will certainly enhance its competitive position.

i9

Of great importance, too, is the fact that increased use of public trans-
portation will ease the downtown parking problem.

Furthermore, it will be recalled from the figures quoted earlier in this
chapter that of the 20 expressway lanes (or equivalent) needed to meet
anticipated east-west traffic increases by 1980 (and to provide a minimum
reduction in present congestion), it was assumed, somewhat arbitrarily,
that the equivalent of two lanes would be provided by unspecified transit
improvements. In addition, four other lanes were unaccounted for on the
basis that further experience might indicate that they would not be
needed. Past experience has shown, however, that future traffic predic-
tions are often apt to turn out to be on the low side. Our ability to
improve public transportation may thus determine whether or not six
expressway lanes (or equivalent) will have to be provided over and above
the East-West Expressway.

Some further aspects of the relationship between rapid transit and
the proposed expressway system are discussed in Chapter V.

Traffic Needs and the Central Business District

It has been pointed out that much of the traffic entering the down-
town area passes through without stopping. This is, of course, the result
of Baltimore’s shape, topography, and pattern of land use. Nearly all such
traffic is local in a metropolitan area sense, but it is through traffic from
the standpoint of the central business district.

It has been suggested that the primary purpose of an expressway
system, insofar as the central business district is concerned, should be to
provide a means for removing from surface streets within the central
business district the traffic that is simply passing through. It is held that
this purpose is of greater importance than the provision of access to the
central business district, particularly since depositipg large volumes of
